foods.name: Tagine
description: Tagine is not just Moroccan food but a significant part of the country’s rich culinary heritage. No wonder this speciality takes its name from the clay pot it was traditionally cooked in. Its conical lid was used to allow condensation which circulated and brought the flavours to the surface making them dense and thus, tasty.

A classic Tagine typically features cuts of lamb or chicken, marinated with several spices like cumin, coriander, cinnamon, and saffron. It is then slow-cooked with a combination of preserved lemons, olives, dried fruits like apricots or dates, and a hint of honey or sugar to bring that perfect balance of flavours. The result is a fragrant, tender, and slightly sweet stew that’s served with crusty Moroccan bread.

It is a ritual for the whole family to sit together around a table and share the first taste of the meal. With changing times, this practice is disappearing but still, many stick by the tradition, especially during festivals or a time of celebration.

foods.name: Couscous
description: Couscous, often referred to as Morocco’s national dish, is a versatile and beloved staple food reflecting the essence of the country’s top cuisine. One of the most famous Moroccan dishes from ancient times, it is a tiny semolina wheat granule that has transcended borders to become a global favourite!

Couscous is prepared by steaming coarsely ground wheat semolina, resulting in delicate, fluffy grains that come in a variety of flavours. It’s typically served with a savoury stew made from ingredients like lamb, chicken, vegetables, and aromatic spices such as cumin, coriander, and saffron.

The couscous absorbs the seasoned juices of the stew, creating a tasteful blend of texture and spices. It is then garnished with chickpeas, raisins, and a drizzle of broth tingling the taste buds to have the first bite.

You can try the succulent Morrocan food anywhere in the world but only the Moroccans know how to serve authentic and delicious couscous dishes. So, waste no time and book your Morocco tour packages today!

foods.name: Harira
description: Harira is a beloved Moroccan soup that holds a special place in the country’s culture. This palatable dish is typically enjoyed during the holy month of Ramadan at the time of breaking fast. However, most people do not wait for a festival or special occasion to try its wonderful flavours and nourishing ingredients.
You can always spice up the soup and experiment with it but here’s how Moroccan people usually prepare Harira.

It started with making a broth in the usual way and later adding tomatoes, lentils, and chickpeas, to the thick texture. To elevate the taste, fragrant spices like cinnamon, ginger, and coriander are also added.
What truly distinguishes Harira from other Moroccan dishes is the inclusion of fresh herbs, particularly cilantro and parsley that lend a vibrant, aromatic depth to the soup.
The broth’s flavour is often enhanced with a squeeze of lemon juice just before serving.
If you are a vegetarian, specifically ask for vegetarian Harira as it usually contains meat, such as lamb or beef, providing an extra layer of richness and taste.

Harira is more than just a soup; it’s a symbol of community and togetherness in Morocco. Families and friends often gather to share a bowl of Harira during Ramadan, reinforcing bonds and traditions. Its nourishing and comforting qualities provide sustenance for both the body and the soul.

foods.name: Chicken Pastilla
description: Pastilla, also known as Bastilla or B’stilla, is a popular cuisine in Morrica prepared by combining sweet and appetizing flavours.

One of the most popular Moroccan street foods, Pastilla symbolizes the harmony and balance found in Moroccan traditions. The heart of Pastilla lies in its luscious filling, which, as per traditions, consists of shredded pigeon meat. However, chicken and seafood versions have replaced the original meat fillings in the present time.

Next, the meat is cooked with a blend of exotic spices such as saffron, cinnamon, ginger, and coriander, creating a rich and fragrant mixture. However, what truly sets Pastilla apart is its unique pastry shell!

Yes, layers of thin, delicate phyllo dough encase the mouth-watering filling, and the dish is baked until golden and crispy. Afterwards, it is dusted with a generous helping of powdered sugar and cinnamon, adding a sweet contrast to the Moroccan dish.
So, if you visit Morocco or other African countries, make sure to find this scrumptious pastry dish. It is available in a variety of flavors and carries an authentic taste.

foods.name: Loubia
description: Loubia, a classic cuisine in Morocco, brings a comforting taste to foodies who are searching for forgotten yet original food recipes around the world.
If cooked well for hours, its humble ingredients and spices will easily transform into a culinary masterpiece.

Loubia is centred around white beans, which are simmered to perfection with aromatic spices like cumin, paprika, and garlic, and often includes small pieces of lamb or beef, although vegetarian variations are also popular.

The dish is further enriched with tomatoes, onions, and a touch of olive oil, resulting in a wholesome stew. Loubia is typically served with crusty Moroccan bread or alongside couscous for a complete meal. You will find this combination in almost all Middle Eastern restaurants around the world but the dish is a top favourite in countries like Tunisia, Libya, and Algeria.

Loubia holds a special place in Moroccan culture and is often enjoyed during family gatherings and celebrations. Its simplicity and heartiness make it a symbol of togetherness and warmth as this delectable cuisine truly embodies the essence of Moroccan hospitality.

foods.name: Italian Meats & Cheese Jacksons
description: Cheese and charcuterie are delicious on their own, but when combined, often with another ingredient (think dried fruit, chocolate or mustard) Charcuterie Director for Columbus, Evan Inada says you might experience what he calls “the perfect bite.” Charcuterie boards can have cheese on them, and cheese boards can have charcuterie on them, yet for all their ease, when it comes to assembling a board, do you worry or wonder which cheese to pair with which meat? The short answer is that you really can’t go wrong by simply selecting a smattering of your favorite salami, cured meats, and cheese. There are, however, a few tips you can follow to ensure thoughtful pairings that will elevate your next cheeseboard.

foods.name: Chebakia
description: Chebakia is a delightful Moroccan pastry that tantalizes taste buds with its sweet and spiced flavours. This unique treat is not only delicious but also visually appealing, because it has a flower-like shape.

The key ingredients in Chebakia include flour, sesame seeds, honey, orange blossom water, rosewater, anise, and a blend of spices such as cinnamon and sesame seeds. However, people love to experiment with the original recipe adding vegetables and sauces to it as well.

To make Chebakia, the dough is mixed with these ingredients and then shaped into flowers or other decorative forms. After shaping, the pastries are deep-fried until they turn a golden brown colour. Once fried, they are dipped into a fragrant honey and rosewater syrup, which imparts a sweet note to the pastries.

Chebakia is not just a delicious dessert; it’s also a symbol of celebration of Moroccan culture. It is often prepared during special occasions like Ramadan and weddings. Chebakia is one of the best Moroccan sweets.

foods.name: B’ssara
description: B’ssara is a flavourful soup, a staple of Moroccan cuisine, known for its hearty and nutritious qualities.

The core ingredients of B’ssara include dried split fava beans, garlic, olive oil, cumin, and paprika. The fava beans are soaked overnight and then cooked until tender. They are blended into a creamy soup along with garlic, cumin, paprika, and a drizzle of olive oil.
The result is a velvety, aromatic soup that is traditionally served with a garnish of fresh cilantro, lemon wedges, and a sprinkle of additional cumin.

B’ssara is not only delicious but also nutritious, as fava beans are packed with protein, fibre, and essential vitamins. It’s a wholesome dish with a rich history, often enjoyed as a breakfast item or as a hearty appetizer.
Its distinctive flavours and creamy texture make B’ssara a unique addition to the culinary landscape of the world, showcasing the global appeal of Moroccan cuisine.
